treatments.name: Induction of Emesis (Vomiting) and Administration of Activated Charcoal
treatments.description: Upon arrival at the clinic, if the ingestion is recent, the veterinarian may administer medication to make the cat vomit, removing the plant material from the stomach. This is often followed by the administration of activated charcoal, which binds to the toxins in the digestive tract to prevent them from being absorbed into the bloodstream.
treatments.notes:
◦ Do not attempt to induce vomiting at home without specific instructions from a veterinarian, as this can cause complications.
    ◦ Ingesting any part of the Jimson Weed plant is considered toxic.Symptomatic Care and Monitoring

treatments.name: Vital Sign Monitoring and Supportive Care
treatments.description: The veterinary team will monitor the cat's heart rate, respiratory rate, and neurological status. Supportive care may include intravenous (IV) fluids to maintain hydration, support blood pressure, and help flush toxins from the body.
treatments.notes: Jimson Weed ingestion causes specific symptoms that require close observation, including rapid pulse (tachycardia), rapid breathing, dilated pupils, and diarrhea.Management of Neurological and Respiratory Signs

treatments.name: Seizure Control and Respiratory Support
treatments.description: If the cat exhibits severe neurological signs such as twitching or convulsions (seizures), the veterinarian may administer anticonvulsant medications. Oxygen therapy or other respiratory support may be provided if the cat is experiencing difficulty breathing.
treatments.notes: Severe cases of Jimson Weed poisoning can lead to coma and death if left untreated. The plant causes significant central nervous system stimulation followed by depression.
